Hello,
I found some articles you might find helpful.
This is an Asset Management plan from Kent, OH. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/20275/Sustainable_Comprehensive_Planning_An_Asset_Management_Approach__Kent_OH
Here is another one from Hillsborough County, FL.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/20291/Hillsborough_Asset_Management_System__Hillsborough_County_FL
You can also read an article about the program Hillsborough County implemented and its strengths.
http://icma.org/en/Article/10853/The_GetItDoneRight_Asset_Management_Program
This article discusses the best ways to optimize your asset management system.
http://icma.org/en/Article/10838/Optimizing_Your_Existing_Asset_Investment
I also included an article about the most important elements of a successful asset management plan.
http://icma.org/en/Article/10924/Criticality_A_Key_Idea_in_Asset_Management

author: Stephanie Klinkenberger
text:
The City of Virginia Beach is seeking information on how other localities are managing their assets. Types of assets included in this research are:
•   Electrical and mechanical equipment (e.g., HVAC systems)
•   Building components (e.g., roofs)
•   Technology (e.g., network equipment, servers)
•   Parks and Recreation Equipment (e.g., boilers, air compressors)
•   Fire station equipment (e.g., refrigerators, stoves)
•   Generators
Virginia Beach currently manages the types of assets listed above by functional area. For example, Public Works manages the building assets, the Technology Department manages all technology, Parks and Recreation manages parks assets, etc.
We are not including the following in this study:
•   The building structures themselves
•   Water and sewer infrastructure
•   Storm water infrastructure
•   Roadways
Our question:  Does your locality manage your assets by functional area or by collecting asset data in one place so you can manage those assets more comprehensively?
title: Assets Management
